ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned assembly and computer architecture.  Much of this course focused on programming concurrency into computers.
Learn how digital systems work, and how certain functions, like concurrency, interrupts, scheduling, etc. are implemented in a microcontroller
This course explored the fundamentals of embedded digital systems. We discussed communication protocols, programming concepts, and security related to these systems.
Programming in C++, digital systems concepts, debugging in software and hardware.
I learned a lot about how physical systems interface with software, their structures, components, protocols, and security
I learned about embedded systems
How digital systems are implemented with considerations such as real-time constraints.
Knowledge of digital systems, denouncing, hardware interface, real time processing and fault tolerant systems.
I learned about embedded systems (software + hardware), scheduling, and concurrency

Gained an understanding of how embedded systems work, from low-level assembly to higher levels of abstraction. Learned about and implemented many of the techniques used in embedded systems, such as analog/digital input/output, concurrency, and scheduling.

The class covered topics that helped students better understand how the systems work and operate (inout/output, assembly language, interrupts), and then how software is written to preform certain work on the systems (scheduling, concurrency, locks). The class is very hands on and covers material that is very applicable to real-world systems
All about embedded systems and the hardware side of computer science. It was great! I learned how to use an Arduino on a very deep level and how the computer actually interacts with the hardware.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths:
Very clear and instructive lectures.  Enjoyable labs.  It really felt like all of the material was actually geared around learning, which isn't true for a lot of courses.

Weaknesses:
I wish less time were spent on concurrency.  It was interesting in the beginning but it really started to drag on after a while.

Strengths: Great lectures and fun labs! Material was also interesting, coming from systems programming background. Learned a lot about hardware as well.
Weaknesses: Labs quizzes and midterms were graded pretty slowly and sometimes had minimal feedback

The course was very technical, and the slides did a good job of covering the highlighting the important material. I wish there had been a textbook to refer to though, if I didn't understand something in class there was no book to turn to for another explanation. The weekly quizzes were good to make sure I was following what happened in the class, and the labs were challenging and encouraged collaboration.

The topics are fun and implementing them on Arduino was a great way to have hands-on experience, especially in the remote pandemic semester

Quite a high level of programming experience is assumed for students taking this course
I loved the weekly quizzes to keep us engaged. The lecture material was also fun, and each unit introduced lots of new concepts and ideas.
the labs were really cool but I felt like 223 should be a prereq for this class, especially for Lab 4 and 5 where we had to use linked list data structures
Professor Manohar explains the course material incredibly well during his lectures. But the online format makes it more difficult to properly coordinate quizzes and labs with your partner.
I loved being hands on, but the grading could be improved by explicitly stating what the grading rubric would be beforehand.

Strengths: labs are very interesting, help us apply material we learned in  class. The TA's were also very helpful in answering questions/helping us. 

Weaknesses: because the lab feedback was posted over a month later we weren't actually able to implement it in future labs, so we ended up making the same mistake again and again, because we weren't aware of it. If the labs were graded more quickly, we could implement the feedback and continue to improve. Also, the last few labs didn't have a rubric.
The material is really interesting and Professor Manohar is a fantastic professor. Some of the labs were annoying to do because they became very difficult to debug.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Online lectures were good. Despite needing a partner to complete labs with, my partner was on campus as well, so things worked out, but other partners had trouble working together remotely.

The class seemed fine over Zoom. Sometimes the labs were tough to do by ourselves as opposed to in a lab with TA's, but the TA's made themselves available over email and via zoom office hours which helped.

Content wise it worked out well, and we could do the programming and testing 
Office hours a bit hard to attend due to time zone differences, but the instructor and TAs were willing to help via email and responded promptly to my queries
Hmmm, I wish that there was more structured lab support, especially for lab 4 where the difficulty really ramped up
I met up with my partner to work on labs which was nice to do in person
Lecture format was good for understanding material. Online format makes engaging with partners, peers, and homework especially challenging.

the live + recorded lectures were very helpful. I found that in being able to go back and re-watch parts I didn't totally understand, I ended up learning a lot more. It actually wasn't until this year that this class and others recorded lectures that I could go back to that I realized just how little I was actually retaining when lectures weren't recorded!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this to anyone in engineering or CS who doesn't actually understand how computers and embedded systems work at the lowest level.
If you are interested in programming and building cool things - yes! The class was great for me, and is probability even better when taken in person!

I would recommend this course to engineers interested in embedded systems. The material is very applicable to designing real world systems, and there are lots of examples that highlight good and bad engineering practices.
Yes, good exploration of embedded systems coding
Yes! It is a great opportunity for a CS student to learn more about the basics of how software runs on hardware. It was really nice to take this class right after 323.
This class is a lot more CS based than other EE classes. If youre an EE major or an EE ABET Major, I recommend taking another CS class before this.
Yes! Loved the labs
Yes in-person, Less enthusiastic yes over Zoom. The lectures and course materials are presented very well, but assessment format is difficult to navigate online.
Yes if they are interested in the interface between software and hardware.

YES take this class! Take it *before* Operating Systems, if you can (I did the reverse, and still found it hugely beneficial, but OS would have been much easier had I taken this class first). Prof Manohar really breaks down how computers...work, and by the end of it, you have a much more comprehensive understanding of the hardware side of things (which would be super helpful for OS classes).
Yes!

Yes, overall I learned a lot. I was worried about not having sufficient experience going in but Prof Manohar and the TA's really make it accessible. It was also great to have a partner for the labs, because it is so enjoyable to get to work with someone else! It's really cool to see how other people might approach the same problem and then learn to choose what we think is the best method.

Yes! Especially if you are EECS, you should absolutely take this course. The material is really interesting and it is really cool to see how the hardware and software come together in embedded systems. Professor Manohar is fantastic. He explains things really well and is always willing to help you understand or give further insight into topics if you are interested. The labs are not too difficult, but they do become really hard to debug so make sure to factor that into the time you need for the assignments.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this class: amazing professor and great class.
Yes, absolutely!  The material is very interesting and it'll make you a better computer scientist.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Handouts on the course website
Class was live, and recorded to view later as well.
Hardware kits mailed out, so we coded on the Arduino
Also virtual office hours
Lectures were also recorded
Problem sets

virtual lab
Virtual lecture 
Office hours
lecture was also recorded
Lectures were recorded.
Live virtual lecture that was recorded and a lab component where supplies were shipped to students to preform remotely
I watched about half the lectures in person and the other half recorded. Learning also took place while working on the physical labs.
Live lecture was recorded for future viewing.
